titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Joseph Bissonette, 1855-1862, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Mary McSparran

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-14 05:20:19 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

change.item: Batch update to change subject links.

did.abstract: The Bissonette mss., 1855-1862, consists of letters and documents of trader and frontiersman Joseph Bisonette, 1814-1894.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Joseph Bissonette was born into a family of explorers in the French region of what is now East St. Louis, Illinois, on 26 May 1814. In the 1840s, he joined Colonel John C. Fremont's expeditions exploring the Rocky Mountains and was an interpreter for Chief Red Cloud. By the 1860s, he had moved to the Nebraska Territory, near Fort Laramie, where he worked as a trader. He eventually moved to the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation and died in Oglala Lakota County, South Dakota, in August 1894.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript materials, 1855-1862, consist of letters and documents relating to Bisonette's claims for losses incurred from depredations committed by Native Americans in the Nebraska Territory.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series: I. Manuscript materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Bissonette mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.
